The rim reads: Republik Ãsterreich 25 Euro. The centere shows electric and a steam driven locomotive]] '''Euro gold and silver commemorative coins''' are special [[euro coins]] [[Mint (coin)|minted]] and issued by member states of the [[Eurozone]]. They are minted mainly in gold and silver, although other [[precious metal]]s are also used on rare occasions. Austria was one of the first twelve countries in the Eurozone to introduce the [[Euro|euro (â¬)]], on 1 January 2002. Since then, the [[Austrian Mint]] has been minting both normal issues of [[Austrian euro coins]] (which are intended for circulation) and commemorative euro coins in gold and silver. These commemorative coins are [[legal tender]] only in Austria, unlike the normal issues of the Austrian euro coins, which are legal tender in every country of the Eurozone. This means that the commemorative coins made of gold and silver cannot be used as money in other countries. Furthermore, as their [[Precious metal#Bullion|bullion value]] generally vastly exceeds their face value,Precious metals in bulk form are known as ''bullion'', and are traded on [[commodity market]]s. Bullion metals may be cast into [[ingot]]s, or minted into [[coin]]s. The defining attribute of bullion is that it is valued by its mass and purity rather than by its [[face value]] as money. these coins are not intended to be used as means of payment at allâalthough this remains possible where they are also legal tender. For this reason, they are usually named '''Collectors' coins'''. Such coins usually [[Commemorative coin|commemorate]] the [[Anniversary|anniversaries]] of [[History|historical events]]. They can also draw attention to [[current events]] of special importance. Austria mints more than ten of these coins on average per year, in gold, silver and [[niobium]], with face values ranging from â¬1.50 to â¬100 (though, as an exceptional case, 15 coins with face value â¬100,000 were minted in 2004). == Summary == As of 3 July 2008, eighty variations of Austrian commemorative coins have been minted: eleven in 2002, twelve in 2003, fourteen in 2004, thirteen in 2005, thirteen in 2006, nine in 2007 and eleven so far in 2008. These special high-value commemorative coins are not to be confused with [[â¬2 commemorative coins]], which are coins designated for circulation and have legal-tender status in all countries of the Eurozone.{{cite web | publisher=[[European Commission]] | url=http://ec.europa.eu/economy_finance/the_euro/notes_coins8787_en.htm | title=Different types of euro coins | accessdate=2008-06-24}} The following table shows the number of coins minted per year. In the first section, the coins are grouped by the metal used, while in the second section they are grouped by their face value.

== Vienna Philharmonic Coin == {|class="wikitable" width="100%" |- | align=center width="330px" nowrap |   | colspan=3 align=left | The Vienna Philharmonic coin{{cite web | url=http://austrian-mint.at/wienerphilharmoniker?l=en | title=The Vienna Philharmonic Coin | publisher=The Austrian Mint | accessdate=2008-07-29}} is struck in pure gold, 999.9 fine (24 karats). It is issued every year, in four different face values, sizes and weights. It is used as an investment product (bullion coin), although it inevitably ends up in private collections. According to the [[World Gold Council]], it was the best-selling gold coin worldwide in 1992, 1995 and 1996. A design of musical instruments representing the [[Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra]], as well as the text ''Wiener Philharmoniker'' ("Vienna Philharmonic"), can be seen on the reverse of the coin. The subject of the [[Obverse and reverse|obverse]] is the great organ in the Golden Hall in Vienna's ''[[Musikverein]]'', the concert hall of the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra. The face value in euros, the weight, alloy purity and year of issue are also inscribed on this side of the coin. Since 1 February 2008, the coin has also been minted in silver. The design of the silver coin is identical to that of the gold coin, except for its face value of 1.50 euro. |- | rowspan=3 align=center | | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬100,000 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Au 999.9 (Gold) | align=center | '''Designer:''' Thomas Pesendorfer |- | align=center | '''Weight:''' {{convert|31.103|kg|lb ozt|0|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Diameter:''' {{convert|370|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Thickness:''' {{convert|20|mm|in|2|abbr=on}}There is no official thickness, this has been physically calculated. |- | colspan=3 align=center | '''Year:''' 2004   '''Mintage:''' 15 coins |- | rowspan=3 align=center | | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬100 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Au 999.9 (Gold) | align=center | '''Designer:''' Thomas Pesendorfer |- | align=center | '''Weight:''' {{convert|31.103|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Diameter:''' {{convert|37|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Thickness:''' {{convert|2.0|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} |- | colspan=3 align=center | '''Year:''' 2006   '''Mintage:''' 82,174

The coin shows a dual representation of [[St. Benedict]] and his sister, [[St. Scholastica]]. St. Benedict is the patron saint of Western Europe and the father of [[western monasticism]]. The directive for monastic life, [[Rule of St Benedict]], initiated by St. Benedict in the sixth century is still valid today.{{cite web | url=http://www.catholic.org/saints/saint.php?saint_id=556 | title=St. Bendict of Nursia | publisher=Catholic Online | accessdate=2008-07-31}} Together with his sister, Benedict also founded an order of nuns who would follow the same instructions.{{cite web | url=http://saintbenedict.org/stscholastica.htm | title=St. Scholastica | publisher=St. Benedict Parish | accessdate=2008-07-31}} The coin shows him holding the Holy Rule while St. Scholastica holds a dove. The [[Obverse and reverse|reverse]] of the coin shows a monk at a writing desk working on a manuscript. It represents the work of the monks in the Middle Ages copying books by hand, so preserving a large storehouse of knowledge. |- | colspan="5" |   |- | rowspan=4 width="330px" nowrap align=center | ! colspan="4" align=center style="background:#eeeeee;"| [[Ambras Castle]]{{cite web | url=http://austrian-mint.at/silbermuenzen?l=en&muenzeSubTypeId=108&muenzeId=335 | title=Ambras Castle coin | publisher=Austrian Mint| accessdate=2008-07-07}} |- | colspan="2" width="50%" align=center | '''Designer:''' Andreas I. The obverse of the coin shows a frontal view of the castle. Built by [[Hans Ulrich von Eggenberg]], the castle demonstrates several astronomical themes: four gigantic towers represent the four elements, 365 windows represent the days of the year, and 24 reception rooms represent the hours of a day. The construction was begun in 1625 and completed in 1642 (after Hans Ulrich's death). The reverse of the coin has a portrait of the scholar and astronomer [[Johannes Kepler]], a contemporary personally acquainted with von Eggenberg and most probably an influence on the design of the castle. In the foreground is Kepler's masterpiece, the model "[[Mysterium Cosmographicum]]". |- | colspan="5" |   |- | rowspan=4 width="330px" nowrap align=center | ! colspan="4" align=center style="background:#eeeeee;"| [[Baroque]]{{cite web | url=http://austrian-mint.at/sondergedenkmuenzen?l=en&muenzeSubTypeId=101&referer=%2Fsondergedenkmuenzen%3Fl%3Den&muenzeId=187 | title=Baroque coin | publisher=Austrian Mint| accessdate=2008-07-07}} |- | colspan="2" width="50%" align=center | '''Designer:''' Andreas I. The obverse of the coin shows the Grand Staircase in the town palace of [[Prince Eugene of Savoy]], currently the Austrian Ministry of Finance. Gods and [[demi-gods]] hold its elevations, while [[Hercules]] stands at the turn of the stairs. The reverse of the coin displays a portrait of Prince Eugene, reminiscent of his equestrian statue in the grounds of the Hofburg Palace in Vienna. A typical [[Baroque]] arrangement of cannon, flags and captured standards decorates the background. |- | colspan="5" |   |- | rowspan=4 width="330px" nowrap align=center | ! colspan="4" align=center style="background:#eeeeee;"| Sculpture{{cite web | url=http://austrian-mint.at/sondergedenkmuenzen?l=en&muenzeSubTypeId=115&referer=%2Fsondergedenkmuenzen%3Fl%3Den&muenzeId=212 | title=Sculpture coin | publisher=Austrian Mint| accessdate=2008-07-07}} |- | colspan="2" width="50%" align=center | '''Designer:''' Herbert WÃ¤hner & Thomas Pesendorfer | colspan="2" width="50%" align=center | '''Mint:''' MÃ¼nze Ãsterreich AG |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬100 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Au 986 (Gold) | align=center | '''Quantity:''' 30,000 | align=center | '''Quality:''' Proof |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' 13 November 2002 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' {{convert|30|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Weight:''' {{convert|16.2|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Issue value:''' â¬368.53
'''Market value:''' â¬300.00{{cite web | url=http://www.eurocoins.com/templates/product.asp?ProductGuid=EUOS2002G2&GroupGuid=12037 | title=Sculpture coin | publisher=eurocoins.com | accessdate=2008-07-07}} |- | colspan="5" align=left | Part of the collection "Art Treasures of Austria". The obverse bears a portrait of one of the greatest Baroque sculptors, [[Georg Rafael Donner]], with the [[Belvedere (palace)|Palace of the Lower Belvedere]] in the background. This palace is currently the Museum of Baroque Art in Vienna, and contains much of Donner's work. The reverse features the [[Providentia Fountain]] (written in the coin as ''Provendentia Brunnen'') in central Vienna, a work by the same sculptor. In the center of the coin, the allegorical figure of [[Providentia]] is displayed with a medallion of the Roman god [[Janus (mythology)|Janus]], who had two faces. Surrounding the fountain there are other symbolic figures representing the tributary rivers of the [[Danube]]; Providentia is enthroned high above the figure of an old man representing the [[Enns River]]. |- |} == 2003 coinage == {|class="wikitable" width="100%" |- | rowspan=4 width="330px" nowrap align=center | ! colspan="4" align=center style="background:#eeeeee;"| 700 Years of City of [[Hall in Tirol|Hall in Tyrol]]{{cite web | url=http://austrian-mint.at/bimetallmuenzen?l=en&muenzeSubTypeId=113&muenzeId=216 | title=700 Years of City of Hall in Tyrol coin | publisher=Austrian Mint| accessdate=2008-07-07}} |- | colspan="2" width="50%" align=center | '''Designer:''' Herbert WÃ¤hner & Helmut Andexlinger | colspan="2" width="50%" align=center | '''Mint:''' [[Austrian Mint|MÃ¼nze Ãsterreich AG]] |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬25 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Ag 900 (Silver) & 7.15g Niob | align=center | '''Quantity:''' 50,000 | align=center | '''Quality:''' UNC |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' 29 January 2003 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' {{convert|34|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Weight:''' {{convert|17.15|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Market value:''' â¬169.95 |- | colspan="5" align=left |With this coin, the [[Austrian Federal Government]] decided to commemorate the city charter granted to the town of Hall in Tyrol 700 years ago. The city of Hall housed an important mint until 1809, when it was closed. It was at Hall in 1486 that the first large silver coin was struck, the "[[Guldengroschen|Guldiner]]". The [[Obverse and reverse|obverse]] of the coin shows a satellite mapping the town of Hall. The [[Obverse and reverse|reverse]] shows the Guldiner silver coin. However, the design is negative, representing a [[coin die]], as a reference to Hall's history as a significant centre for minting coins. This is the first time a coin die has been reproduced on an Austrian coin, giving a distinctive character to this extraordinary issue. In the silver ring is also written ''700 Jahre Stadt Hall in Tirol'', meaning "700 Years of City of Hall in Tyrol". |- | colspan="5" |   |- | rowspan=4 width="330px" nowrap align=center | ! colspan="4" align=center style="background:#eeeeee;"| [[Charity (virtue)|Christian Charity]]{{cite web | url=http://austrian-mint.at/sondergedenkmuenzen?l=en&muenzeSubTypeId=114&referer=%2Fsondergedenkmuenzen%3Fl%3Den&muenzeId=204 | title=Christian Charity coin | publisher=Austrian Mint| accessdate=2008-07-07}} |- | colspan="2" width="50%" align=center | '''Designer:''' Helmut Andexlinger | colspan="2" width="50%" align=center | '''Mint:''' MÃ¼nze Ãsterreich AG |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬50 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Au 986 (Gold) | align=center | '''Quantity:''' 50,000 | align=center | '''Quality:''' Proof |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' 12 March 2003 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' {{convert|22|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Weight:''' {{convert|10.14|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Issue value:''' â¬230.34

The obverse of the coin shows a modern instance of Christian charity. A [[nun]] working as a nurse comforts a sick man in accordance with Christ's admonition. The coin shows the Good Samaritan with the wounded man on his horse as he takes him for medical attention. The coin's obverse shows the castle of Artstetten standing above the [[Danube|Danube River]] on the threshold to the region known as the [[Wachau]]. First recorded in the 13th century, the castle, today, presents a striking sight from afar, with its corner towers and unique "onion-domes." The reverse shows the entrance to the crypt of the [[House of Hohenberg|Hohenberg family]]. There are two portraits to the left, showing [[Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria|Archduke Franz Ferdinand]] and his wife [[Sophie, Duchess of Hohenberg]]. |- | colspan="5" |   |- | rowspan=4 width="330px" nowrap align=center |   ! colspan="4" align=center style="background:#eeeeee;"| [[Vienna Secession|Secession]]{{cite web | url=http://austrian-mint.at/sondergedenkmuenzen?l=en&muenzeSubTypeId=120&referer=%2Fsondergedenkmuenzen%3Fl%3Den&muenzeId=344 | title=Secession coin | publisher=Austrian Mint| accessdate=2008-07-07}} |- | colspan="2" width="50%" align=center | '''Designer:''' Helmut Andexlinger | colspan="2" width="50%" align=center | '''Mint:''' MÃ¼nze Ãsterreich AG |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬100 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Au 986 (Gold) | align=center | '''Quantity:''' 30,000 | align=center | '''Quality:''' Proof |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' 10 November 2004 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' {{convert|30|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Weight:''' {{convert|16.22|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Market value:''' â¬349.00 |- | colspan="5" align=left | Part of the collection "[[Art Nouveau|Jugendstil]]". On the obverse is a view of the [[Secession hall (Austria)|Secession exhibition hall]] situated in [[Vienna]]. The building was called the Secession as it was the seceding of the [[Vienna Secession|"rebel artists"]] from the long-established fine art institution that gave rise to this excellent structure. The reverse features a small portion of the world famous "[[Beethoven Frieze]]" by [[Gustav Klimt]]. She represents the Austrian Republic and is surrounded by the coat of arms of the nine federal provinces. The River Gate was built during the years 1903 to 1906 and was opened to the general public on 15 November 1906. In celebration of its centennial, in 2006, the gate has been chosen as the main motif for this commemorative coin issue. The obverse depicts the gate from its more prominent side, encasing the tunnelled exit where the River Wien flows into the City Park. The reverse shows one of the ladies that flank the entrance from the street. In its entirety, the gate forms one of the most beautiful [[Art Nouveau|Jugendstil]] scenes to be found in all of [[Vienna]]. |- |} == 2007 coinage == {|class="wikitable" width="100%" |- | rowspan=4 width="330px" nowrap align=center |   ! colspan="4" align=center style="background:#eeeeee;"| 100 Years Universal Male Suffrage{{cite web | url=http://www.austrian-mint.at/silbermuenzen?l=en&muenzeSubTypeId=84&muenzeId=560 | title=100 Years Universal Male Suffrage coin | publisher=Austrian Mint| accessdate=2008-07-07}} |- | colspan="2" width="50%" align=center | '''Designer:''' Herbert WÃ¤hner | colspan="2" width="50%" align=center | '''Mint:''' [[Austrian Mint|MÃ¼nze Ãsterreich AG]] |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬5 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Ag 800 (Silver) | align=center | '''Quantity:'''

A constitutional system with a parliament, the [[Reichsrat (Austria)|Reichsrat]] was created, and a bill of rights was enacted also in 1867. [[Suffrage]] to the Reichstag's lower house was gradually expanded until 1907, when equal suffrage for all male citizens was introduced. This coin design is based on a historic photo of the opening session of Parliament in 1907, after the elections. The two oval portraits in the foreground are of the [[Franz Joseph I of Austria|Emperor Franz Joseph]] and [[Baron Max Wladimir von Beck|Max Wladimir von Beck]], who were responsible for putting the reform through. |- | colspan="5" |   |- | rowspan=4 width="330px" nowrap align=center |   ! colspan="4" align=center style="background:#eeeeee;"| [[Gerard van Swieten]]{{cite web | url=http://austrian-mint.at/sondergedenkmuenzen?l=en&muenzeSubTypeId=203&muenzeId=561 | title=Gerard van Swieten coin | publisher=Austrian Mint| accessdate=2008-07-07}} |- | colspan="2" width="50%" align=center | '''Designer:''' Helmut Andexlinger | colspan="2" width="50%" align=center | '''Mint:''' MÃ¼nze Ãsterreich AG |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬50 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Au 986 (Gold) | align=center | '''Quantity:''' 50,000 | align=center | '''Quality:''' Proof |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' 31 January 2007 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' {{convert|22|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Weight:''' {{convert|10.14|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Issue value:''' â¬230.34 |- | colspan="5" align=left | Part of the collection "Celebrated Physicians of Austria". Gerard van Swieten is original from the Netherlands. The [[Maria Theresa of Austria|Empress Maria Theresa]] chose him as her personal physician; he then became the founder of the [[First Vienna School of Medicine]]. His legacy to the world of medicine made him the choice for the first coin in this new gold series "Celebrated Physicians of Austria". The obverse shows his portrait holding a book. The reverse shows the view of the [[Austrian Academy of Sciences|Academy of Sciences]], the handwritten text of the reform "''Plan pour la facultÃ© de medicine''", and a branch of the [[Swietenia mahagoni]]. Also the text ''Akademie der Wissenschaften'' ("Academy of Sciences") can be read in this side of the coin. |- | colspan="5" |   |- | rowspan=4 width="330px" nowrap align=center |   ! colspan="4" align=center style="background:#eeeeee;"| Austrian Aviation{{cite web | url=http://austrian-mint.at/bimetallmuenzen?l=en&muenzeSubTypeId=113&muenzeId=562 | title=Austrian Aviation coin | publisher=Austrian Mint| accessdate=2008-07-07}} |- | colspan="2" width="50%" align=center | '''Designer:''' Herbert WÃ¤hner & Thomas Pesendorfer | colspan="2" width="50%" align=center | '''Mint:''' MÃ¼nze Ãsterreich AG |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬25 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Ag 900 (Silver) & 6.5g Niob | align=center | '''Quantity:''' 65,000 | align=center | '''Quality:''' UNC |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' 28 February 2007 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' {{convert|34|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Weight:''' {{convert|16.5|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Issue value:''' â¬49.95 |- | colspan="5" align=left | The obverse shows a view into the [[cockpit]] of a modern passenger airplane. In the lower right corner the coat-of-arms of the [[Abbey of Melk]] (the crossed keys of St. Peter) can be seen. The reverse depicts a scene of a train pulled by the steam locomotive ''Ajax'' crossing the bridge over the [[Danube]] on the first public run from the [[Wien Praterstern railway station|North Railway Station]] in Vienna to [[Deutsch-Wagram]] on 6 January 1838. The run caused quite a sensation, being watched and cheered by crowds of Viennese along its route. The obverse shows a wide view of the Abbey of Seckau looking west. Located in the center is the great [[Romanesque architecture|Romanesque]] basilica with its two mighty towers surrounded by the [[Baroque architecture|Baroque]] monastic buildings. The reverse shows a view from the main entrance of the church to the high altar, the [[Crucifixion|mediaeval crucifixion]] group hanging on four massive chains can be depicted. The [[Seckau Abbey|Abbey of Seckau]] is located in the province of [[Styria]]. Founded in 1142 it was the bishopâs seat for Styria until 1782 when [[Joseph II, Holy Roman Emperor|Emperor Joseph II]] suppressed the abbey and moved the bishopâs seat to [[Graz]]. 100 years later, the abbey was then purchased by [[Benedictine|Benedictine monks]] from the [[Beuron Archabbey|German abbey of Beuron]] and monastic life was restored to Seckau. The current [[Gothic architecture|Gothic]] vaulting replaced the original wooden roofing after a fire that took place in 1259. |- | colspan="5" |   |- | rowspan=4 width="330px" nowrap align=center |   ! colspan="4" align=center style="background:#eeeeee;"| [[Imperial Crown of the Holy Roman Empire]]{{cite web | url=http://www.austrian-mint.at/sondergedenkmuenzen?l=en&muenzeSubTypeId=217&referer=%2Fsondergedenkmuenzen%3Fl%3Den&muenzeId=634 | title=The Crown of the Holy Roman Empire coin | publisher=Austrian Mint | accessdate=2008-10-01}} |- | colspan="2" width="50%" align=center | '''Designer:''' Thomas Pesendorfer | colspan="2" width="50%" align=center | '''Mint:''' MÃ¼nze Ãsterreich AG |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬100 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Au 986 (Gold) | align=center | '''Quantity:''' 30,000 | align=center | '''Quality:''' Proof |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' 5 November 2008 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' {{convert|30|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Weight:''' {{convert|16|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Issue value:''' â¬385.00 |- | colspan="5" align=left | The first coin of the series âCrowns of the House of Habsburgâ; a five-part gold coin series. The obverse shows the [[Imperial Crown of the Holy Roman Empire]]. This octagonal imperial crown is made of gold and precious stones; it was made especially for the coronation of [[Otto I, Holy Roman Emperor|Emperor Otto I]] in the year 962. The reverse shows the Emperor Otto I with old [[St. Peter's Basilica]] in Rome in the background, where his coronation took place. |- |} == 2008 Europe Taler == {|class="wikitable" width="100%" |- | rowspan=4 width="330px" nowrap align=center | ! colspan="4" align=center style="background:#eeeeee;"| Europe Taler 2008{{cite web | url=http://www.easier.com/view/Travel/Attractions_and_Events/article-185048.html | title=Hall in Tirol presents the biggest silver medal-coin in the world.| accessdate=2008-07-07 | publisher=Easier Travel}} |- | colspan="2" width="50%" align=center | '''Designer:''' Thomas Pesendorfer & Herbert WÃ¤hner | colspan="2" width="50%" align=center | '''Mint:''' MÃ¼nze Ãsterreich AG |- | align=center | '''Value:''' N/AThe taler does not have a face value, because it is considered a medal-coin. | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Ag 999 (Silver) | align=center | '''Quantity:''' 1 | align=center | '''Quality:''' Proof |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' June 2008 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' {{convert|360|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Weight:''' {{convert|20.08|kg|lb ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Issue value:''' N/AThis mega-coin is not for sale, is currently under exhibition in the Hall Mint Museum. |- | colspan="5" align=left |The largest silver medal-coin in the world was launched in [[Hall in Tirol]]. It was displayed to the public on the occasion of the [[UEFA Euro 2008|2008 European Championship of Football]] in Austria and Switzerland. The design on the obverse of the medal is five centuries old. 500 years ago in [[Trento|Trient]], [[Maximilian I, Holy Roman Emperor|Kaiser Maximilian I]] crowned himself Emperor and a commemorative coin was issued by the Mint in Hall. An inscription in this side read: ''MAXIMILIANVS DEI GRA[tia] ROM[anorum] IMP[erator] SEMP[er] AVG[vstvs] ARCHIDVX AVSTRIE'' ("Maximilian, by the grace of God, Emperor of the Romans, Forever Augustus, Archduke of Austria"). This is the oldest known use of the word ''Europe'' on a coin. The image on the obverse corresponds to the time of Maximilian's coronation in 1508. It shows the emperor mounted in armour on a horse; in his hand he holds a banner with the imperial symbol, the double eagle. The reverse shows important people in the history of Europe. One can easily make out the features of: [[Martin Luther]], symbolising the transition from the Middle Ages to the modern period, his reformation affecting the religious and spiritual landscape of Europe; [[Antonio Vivaldi]], exemplifying the importance of European cultural life; [[James Watt]], 18th-century inventor of the first [[steam engine]], representing the industrialization of Europe and the age of technical innovation and [[Bertha von Suttner]], the Nobel Peace Prize winner. In between the scenes dipicting the work of these notable Europeans is a tower, the symbol of the Hall Mint. Stars, a symbol of [[European Union|European unity]], surround the tower and symbolize the transition to the European Union of the 21st century.{{cite web | url=http://europataler.at/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5&Itemid=10&lang=en | title=The Europe Taler Coin. | publisher=The Europe Taler Web Site | accessdate=2008-07-07}} The Latin text ''PLVRIVMQ(ve) EUROPE PROVINCIAR[um] REX ET PRINCEPS POTENTISIM[us]'' ("Of many European countries, King and most powerful prince") is also depicted in this side of the medal. |- | colspan="5" |   |- | rowspan=4 width="330px" nowrap align=center | ! colspan="4" align=center style="background:#eeeeee;"| Europe Taler 2008 |- | colspan="2" width="50%" align=center | '''Designer:''' Thomas Pesendorfer & Herbert WÃ¤hner | colspan="2" width="50%" align=center | '''Mint:''' MÃ¼nze Ãsterreich AG |- | align=center | '''Value:''' N/A | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Ag 999 (Silver) | align=center | '''Quantity:''' 2008 | align=center | '''Quality:''' [[Patina]]ted and [[Vitreous enamel|Enamelled]] |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' June 2008 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' {{convert|60|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Weight:''' {{convert|120|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Issue value:''' â¬108{{cite web | url=http://europataler.at/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=7&Itemid=5&lang=en | title=2008 Europe Taler Replica details | publisher=The Europe Taler Web Site | accessdate=2008-07-07}} |- | colspan="5" align=left | A special minting of replicas of the 2008 Europe Taler also celebrate the occasion. The design of the replicas is exactly the same, but dramatically reduced in size. |} == 2009 Coinage == The following is the schedule for next year issues.{{cite web | url=https://www.austrian-mint.at/praegeprogramme?l=en | publisher=MÃ¼nze Ãsterreich AG | accessdate=2009-10-14 | title=Issuing Programme 2009}} {|class="wikitable" width="100%" |- | rowspan=4 width="330px" nowrap align=center |   ! colspan="4" align=center style="background:#eeeeee;"| 200th Anniversary of the Death of [[Joseph Haydn]]{{cite web | url=http://www.austrian-mint.at/silbermuenzen?l=en&muenzeSubTypeId=84&muenzeId=638 | title=200th Anniversiary of the Death of Joseph Haydn Commemorative Coin | publisher=[[Austrian Mint]] | accessdate=2008-12-16}} |- | colspan="2" width="50%" align=center | '''Designer:''' Helmut Andexlinger | colspan="2" width="50%" align=center | '''Mint:''' [[Austrian Mint|MÃ¼nze Ãsterreich AG]] |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬5 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Ag 800 (Silver) | align=center | '''Quantity:'''

The official side of the nine-sided coin displays the shields of the nine Federal Provinces of Austria and the denomination of 5 euros. |- | colspan="5" |   |- | rowspan=4 width="330px" nowrap align=center |   ! colspan="4" align=center style="background:#eeeeee;"| [[Theodor Billroth]]{{cite web | url=http://www.austrian-mint.at/sondergedenkmuenzen?l=en&muenzeSubTypeId=203&referer=%2Fsondergedenkmuenzen%3Fl%3Den&muenzeId=662 | title=Theodor Billroth Commemorative Coin | publisher=[[Austrian Mint]] | accessdate=2009-01-23}} |- | colspan="2" width="50%" align=center | '''Designer:''' Helmut Andexlinger & Herbert WÃ¤hner | colspan="2" width="50%" align=center | '''Mint:''' MÃ¼nze Ãsterreich AG |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬50 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Au 986 (Gold) | align=center | '''Quantity:''' 50,000 | align=center | '''Quality:''' Proof |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' 11 February 2009 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' {{convert|22|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Weight:''' {{convert|10|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Issue value:''' â¬258{{cite web | url=https://www2.austrian-mint.at/mueshop/catalog/setCurrentItem/(layout=6_1_59_49_5_2&uiarea=2&ctype=areaDetails&next=seeItem&carea=0000000001&citem=00000000010000000053)/.do | title=50 Euro gold coin Theodor Billroth | publisher=[[Austrian Mint]] | accessdate=2009-01-23}} |- | colspan="5" align=left |This coin will be part of the series "Celebrated Physicians of Austria" Born on the island of [[RÃ¼gen]], Germany, in 1829, [[Theodor Billroth]] studied medicine in [[GÃ¶ttingen]], Berlin, and [[Vienna]]. While pioneering various operation techniques in [[abdominal surgery]], he recognised the role of bacteria as a cause of post-operative traumatic fever. By introducing [[antiseptic]]s, Billroth enhanced the future safety of all operating theatres. In 1879 he founded the Rudolfiner House in Vienna to train not only doctors and surgeons, but also female nurses. He died in 1894 at the age of 64. In the obverse of the coin, a portrait of Billroth is depicted, together with the [[rod of Asclepius]] and the years of his birth and death. On the reverse is a representation of him practicing surgery. On the left bottom portion of the coin, the Rudolfiner hospital can be seen. The text "''DER BILLROTHÂ´SCHE HÃRSAAL''" in German, is written along the bottom of the coin. |- | colspan="5" |   |- | rowspan=4 width="330px" nowrap align=center |   ! colspan="4" align=center style="background:#eeeeee;"| [[International Year of Astronomy]]{{cite web | url=http://www.austrian-mint.at/bimetallmuenzen?l=en&muenzeSubTypeId=113&muenzeId=664 | title=Year of Astronomy Commemorative Coin | publisher=[[Austrian Mint]] | accessdate=3 February 2009}} |- | colspan="2" width="50%" align=center | '''Designer:''' Herbert WÃ¤hner | colspan="2" width="50%" align=center | '''Mint:''' MÃ¼nze Ãsterreich AG |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬25 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Ag 900 (Silver) & Niobium | align=center | '''Quantity:''' 65,000 | align=center | '''Quality:''' Special UNC |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' 11 March 2009 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' {{convert|34|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Weight:''' {{convert|9|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Issue value:''' â¬41{{cite web | url=https://www2.austrian-mint.at/mueshop/catalog/setCurrentItem/(layout=6_1_59_49_5_2&uiarea=2&ctype=areaDetails&next=seeItem&carea=0000000046&citem=00000000460000000002)/.do | title=Year of Astronomy coin | publisher=[[Austrian Mint]] | accessdate=3 February 2009}} |- | colspan="5" align=left | The theme of this coin is the [[International Year of Astronomy]], 2009. It also commemorates the 400th anniversary of the invention of [[Refracting telescope#Galilean telescope|Galileo's telescope]], used in 1609 to observe the moon. The obverse shows a portion of a portrait of [[Galileo Galilei]] (1564â1642) and his telescope. The background shows one of his first drawings of the surface of the moon, he was the first to report lunar mountains and [[Impact crater|craters]]. In the silver ring other telescopes are depicted: the [[Isaac Newton Telescope]], the observatory in [[KremsmÃ¼nster Abbey]], a modern telescope, a [[radio telescope]] and a [[Space observatory|space telescope]]. The reverse shows a [[satellite]] investigating the surface of the [[moon]]. The silver ring depicts a portion of the [[earth]] with a stylised [[sun]] shining. The color of the niobium phil is golden yellow, representing the sun. |- | colspan="5" |   |- | rowspan=4 width="330px" nowrap align=center | N/AThis information has not been released to the public yet ! colspan="4" align=center style="background:#eeeeee;"| The Basilisk of Vienna |- | colspan="2" width="50%" align=center | '''Designer:''' Thomas Pesendorfer | colspan="2" width="50%" align=center | '''Mint:''' MÃ¼nze Ãsterreich AG |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬10 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Ag 925 (Silver) | align=center | '''Quantity:'''
